title: New mum almost died after contracting flesh-eating disease following caesarean
text:
Krista Parise caught necrotising fasciitis after having an emergency C-section (Picture: Jam Press)

A mother who caught a flesh-eating disease after a C-section has urged new mums to seek medical help if they feel any pain in the weeks after giving birth.

Krista Parise, 32, was diagnosed with necrotising fasciitis, an infection which targets the body’s soft tissues, after she was sent for an emergency C-section.

The first-time-mum, from New York, almost died when she contracted the life-threatening disease, which was only discovered over a week after her surgery.

In June, Krista gave birth to her first child, Sal, and was discharged from hospital with no complications two days later.

After she woke up the next day with a fever, she saw her doctor but was sent back home.

But over the next few days, her temperature shot up and she experienced crippling pain around her stomach.

Krista was allowed home two days after giving birth to her son (Picture: Jam Press)

Although she was prescribed painkillers, the pain became so bad Krista struggled to walk and couldn’t shower because her skin was too tender.

Krista later found out her cousin was allergic to surgical tape and wondered if she could be too.

She said: ‘I reached down to touch my area, and I felt a blister. And I thought “What was that?”

‘I had all big puss bubbles all along my lower stomach. I freaked out and called my mum and boyfriend.’

Krista was rushed to hospital where medics tried to analyse what was causing the problem and after an emergency life-saving procedure, she was diagnosed with the flesh-eating disease.

Krista’s condition was so severe the bacteria had already eaten through the tissue holding together her intestines and she would have died had she waited any longer for treatment.

Krista spent two weeks in isolation with the infection (Picture: Jam Press)

Doctors said she had picked up the infection during the C-section and was kept in isolation for two weeks.

During that time new mum Krista was not allowed to see Sal due to fears the infection could spread.

She explained: ‘I couldn’t see my son because he was too little to come to hospital with all the germs and everything.

‘As a new mother my whole plan changed. I couldn’t breast feed him because of all the meds I was on.

‘I had FaceTimed him to see him, but the main thing on my mind was that he was ok.’

After she was finally discharged, Krista, who was still in severe pain, hired a live-in nurse to help her.

Krista is still having surgery and scans (Picture: Jam Press)

Although her condition has now improved, Krista still needs surgery and further scans. A nurse also comes to help her twice a week.

Since her traumatic experience, Krista has urged other mothers who feel pain in the days and weeks after giving birth to seek urgent medical help.

She added: ‘After any type of birth, if you don’t feel good and feel you’re not yourself, don’t take it lightly, go get check out.

‘Had I just went to my doctors office, and if they took my white blood cell count they would have seen that something was very wrong.’
